survival_orientation.purpose: Defines how an individual's nervous system anticipates and responds to perceived threat. Determines baseline safety strategies, reactive patterns, and adaptive survival logic.

axes.description: Orients toward perceived danger, instability, or betrayal. Hypervigilance as default state.
Orients toward managing uncertainty, autonomy, and outcomes. Seeks predictability through control.
Orients toward relational security and belonging. Avoids social rejection, prioritizes connection.
Orients toward competence, performance, and success. Avoids inadequacy or perceived failure.

sub_motives.description: Fear of emotional or physical abandonment; drives clinging, reassurance-seeking, or compliance.
Expectation of deception or hidden agendas; drives distrust, testing behaviors, and vigilance.
Defense of personal control; reacts strongly to constraint, manipulation, or coercion.
Fear of inadequacy; survival linked to performance or perceived capability.
Need for predictability, routine, and structure; threat arises from disruption or chaos.
Assumes the world is unstable or dangerous; prepares for sudden negative shifts.

behavioral_indicators.description: Scanning environment for threat, reading microexpressions, expecting danger.
Conflict avoidance through appeasement or over-accommodation.
Rigid planning and contingency stacking to avoid uncertainty.
Sabotaging opportunities to maintain familiar patterns or avoid failure exposure.
Withdrawal, emotional numbing, or evasion of high-stakes situations.

predictive_signals.description: Likelihood of escalation or shutdown under stress, shaped by perceived threat type.
Longposure-term relational stability patterns across stress, rupture, and repair cycles.
Susceptibility to coercion, flattery, or pressure depending on core survival motive.
Expected coping behaviors in crises; determines meltdown, freeze, or hyperfunction patterns.
